title: Is the judgement legitimate even if it does not show up on your credit report?
question: I received a default judgement from a collection agency but their account and the judgement info are not on the credit report i had recently pulled. are they legitimate? does that happen at all? it is in the correct amount and the collection agency did show me a proof of their dept purchased from the original creditor (bank) I had an account under but i'm wondering why they don't show up on the credit report. (or am I lucky for it not showing up?)
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Default judgment
answers:
Credit reports often show judgments, but not always. The validity of the judgment is based on what the court signed - is there a signed judgment from the court or not? That is what is most important and what controls in this matter. If the judgment is valid, it typically will show up on your credit eventually. Best of luck.

Credit reports are only as good as the information received by the companies which furnished the information and outside vendors which obtain court judgments and other public records for purposes of reporting them on the credit reports. However, if the credit reporting agency cannot match an individual consumer with a valid judgment or they have an incorrect match, then the judgment would not appear on the correct credit report or on any credit report.

Thus, the fact that a credit report is missing information about a debt or about a judgment, does not mean that the consumer does not owe the debt or judgment. The opposite is also true: that a debt appeared on a consumer's credit report does not mean that they owe it, because a high error rate in credit reports is well documented. All errors should be disputed in writing, by certified mail, return receipt requested. Please see the link to my sample letters, below.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
www.facebook.com/SoCalConsumerLawyer
Twitter: @RStempler

A judgment not being on a credit report has no bearing on the validity of the judgment. If there is a signed order by a judge re the default judgment then the judgment is valid. Perhaps the company has not yet reported it to the credit bureau. Perhaps they reported it to a bureau that you have yet to check. Although the judgment has temporarily not affected your credit, you are still liable for the judgment and subject to levies/garnishments/liens unless you file for bankruptcy or come to sort of post-judgment settlement agreement with them. One of us may be able to help you. Best of luck.
